paragraphs.text:
%md
## Text Analytics
#### In which we analyze the Mood of the nation from inferences on SOTU by the POTUS
####   (State Of The Union addresses by the President Of The US)
 
#####Goal is to find interesting words in the speeches that reflect the times.
 
#####Am sure Lincoln didn't worry about WMDs and Iraq; neither did George Washington about inflation, Wall Street and Jobs.

result.msg:
Text Analytics

In which we analyze the Mood of the nation from inferences on SOTU by the POTUS

(State Of The Union addresses by the President Of The US)

Goal is to find interesting words in the speeches that reflect the times.
Am sure Lincoln didn't worry about WMDs and Iraq; neither did George Washington about inflation, Wall Street and Jobs.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
from pyspark.context import SparkContext
print "Running Spark Version %s" % (sc.version)

result.msg: Running Spark Version 1.6.0

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
from pyspark.conf import SparkConf
conf = SparkConf()
print conf.toDebugString()

%md
#### MapReduce in one line !
#### 1. Split lines into words on space
#### 2. Create key-value pair with key=word, value = 1
#### 3. Sum value for each word (er ... key)
#### 4. Then we get key-value RDD with key=word and value = number of times the word occured in a document

result.msg:
MapReduce in one line !

1. Split lines into words on space

2. Create key-value pair with key=word, value = 1

3. Sum value for each word (er … key)

4. Then we get key-value RDD with key=word and value = number of times the word occured in a document

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
# imports
from operator import add
%md ###Let us strip the unwanted characters and convert all words to lowercase

result.msg: Let us strip the unwanted characters and convert all words to lowercase

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
lines = sc.textFile("data/sotu/2009-2014-BO.txt")
word_count_bo = lines.flatMap(lambda x: x.split(' ')).\
    map(lambda x: (x.lower().rstrip().lstrip().rstrip(',').rstrip('.'), 1)).\
    reduceByKey(add)
print word_count_bo.count()
# 6658 without lower, 6299 with lower, rstrip,lstrip 4835

%pyspark
lines = sc.textFile("data/sotu/2009-2015-BO.txt")
word_count_bo_2015 = lines.flatMap(lambda x: x.split(' ')).\
    map(lambda x: (x.lower().rstrip().lstrip().rstrip(',').rstrip('.').replace(u"\u2019", "'"), 1)).\
    reduceByKey(add)
print word_count_bo_2015.count()

%pyspark
lines = sc.textFile("data/sotu/2016-BO.txt")
word_count_bo_2016 = lines.flatMap(lambda x: x.split(' ')).\
    map(lambda x: (x.lower().rstrip().lstrip().rstrip(',').rstrip('.').replace(u"\u2019", "'"), 1)).\
    reduceByKey(add)
print word_count_bo_2016.count()

%pyspark
lines = sc.textFile("data/sotu/2001-2008-GWB.txt")
word_count_gwb = lines.flatMap(lambda x: x.split(' ')).\
    map(lambda x: (x.lower().rstrip().lstrip().rstrip(',').rstrip('.'), 1)).\
    reduceByKey(add)
print word_count_gwb.count()

%pyspark
lines = sc.textFile("data/sotu/1994-2000-WJC.txt")
word_count_wjc = lines.flatMap(lambda x: x.split(' ')).\
    map(lambda x: (x.lower().rstrip().lstrip().rstrip(',').rstrip('.'), 1)).\
    reduceByKey(add)
print "WJC = %d" %(word_count_wjc.count())
#
lines = sc.textFile("data/sotu/1961-1963-JFK.txt")
word_count_jfk = lines.flatMap(lambda x: x.split(' ')).\
    map(lambda x: (x.lower().rstrip().lstrip().rstrip(',').rstrip('.'), 1)).\
    reduceByKey(add)
print "JFK = %d" %(word_count_jfk.count())
#
lines = sc.textFile("data/sotu/1934-1945-FDR.txt")
word_count_fdr = lines.flatMap(lambda x: x.split(' ')).\
    map(lambda x: (x.lower().rstrip().lstrip().rstrip(',').rstrip('.'), 1)).\
    reduceByKey(add)
print "FDR = %d" %(word_count_fdr.count())
#
lines = sc.textFile("data/sotu/1861-1864-AL.txt")
word_count_al = lines.flatMap(lambda x: x.split(' ')).\
    map(lambda x: (x.lower().rstrip().lstrip().rstrip(',').rstrip('.'), 1)).\
    reduceByKey(add)
print "AL  = %d" %(word_count_al.count())
#
lines = sc.textFile("data/sotu/1790-1796-GW.txt")
word_count_gw = lines.flatMap(lambda x: x.split(' ')).\
    map(lambda x: (x.lower().rstrip().lstrip().rstrip(',').rstrip('.'), 1)).\
    reduceByKey(add)
print "GW  = %d" %(word_count_gw.count())

%pyspark
BO_df = word_count_bo.sortBy(lambda x: x[1],ascending=False).toDF(["word","count"])
BO_df.show(5)
BO_df.registerTempTable("BO")

%sql
SELECT * FROM BO LIMIT 15

result.msg:
word	count
the	1812
and	1375
to	1351
of	1013
a	802
that	778
we	719
our	698
in	637
	585
for	411
is	370
will	355
this	332
i	331

paragraphs.text: %md ### Yikes, we need to filter out the common words

result.msg: Yikes, we need to filter out the common words

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark common_words = ["","us","has","all", "they", "from", "who","what","on","by","more","as","not","their","can", "new","it","but","be","are","--","i","have","this","will","for","with","is","that","in", "our","we","a","of","to","and","the","that's","or","make","do","you","at","it\'s","than", "if","know","last","about","no","just","now","an","because","

we","why","we\'ll","how", "two","also","every","come","we've","year","over","get","take","one","them","we\'re","need", "want","when","like","most","-","been","first","where","so","these","they\'re","good","would", "there","should","-->","

%pyspark
word_count_bo_clean = word_count_bo_1.filter(lambda x: x[0] not in common_words)
print word_count_bo_clean.count()
bo_df = word_count_bo_clean.toDF(["word","count"])
bo_df.show(10)

word_count_gwb_clean.count()

#

print "*** JFK = %d" %(word_count_jfk_clean.count())
#

#
word_count_al_clean = word_count_al.filter(lambda x: x[0] not in common_words)
print "*** AL = %d" %(word_count_al_clean.count())
#
word_count_gw_clean = word_count_gw.filter(lambda x: x[0] not in common_words)
print "*** GW = %d" %(word_count_gw_clean.count())

### 1. word_count_gw_clean = 1790-1796-GW.txt
### 2. word_count_bo_2015_clean

What mood was the country in 1790-1796 vs 2009-2015 ?

Hint:

1. word_count_gw_clean = 1790-1796-GW.txt

2. word_count_bo_2015_clean

paragraphs.text:
%md 
# Coding Exercise
## What mood was the country in 1790-1796 vs 2009-2015 ?
### POA:
### 1. Read 1790-1796-GW.txt
### 2. Process out common words et al
### 3. Check top 20 words by count
### 4. Difference & Explain

result.msg:
Coding Exercise

What mood was the country in 1790-1796 vs 2009-2015 ?

POA:

1. Read 1790-1796-GW.txt

2. Process out common words et al

3. Check top 20 words by count

4. Difference & Explain

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Oh, wait - One More/Last Thing
### The debates !!!

result.msg:
Oh, wait - One More/Last Thing

The debates !!!

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
lines = sc.textFile("data/sotu/debates/RepublicanDebate-2016.txt")
rd = lines.flatMap(lambda x: x.split(' ')).\
    map(lambda x: (x.lower().rstrip().lstrip().rstrip(',').rstrip('.'), 1)).\
    reduceByKey(add)
print rd.count()

%pyspark
rd_1 = rd.sortBy(lambda x: x[1],ascending=False)
rd_1.toDF(["word","count"]).show(5)

%pyspark
rd_clean = rd.filter(lambda x: x[0] not in common_words)
print rd_clean.count()
#
rd_1 = rd_clean.sortBy(lambda x: x[1],ascending=False)
rd_1.toDF(["word","count"]).show(5)

%pyspark
lines = sc.textFile("data/sotu/debates/DemocraticDebate-2016.txt")
dd = lines.flatMap(lambda x: x.split(' ')).\
    map(lambda x: (x.lower().rstrip().lstrip().rstrip(',').rstrip('.'), 1)).\
    reduceByKey(add)
print dd.count()
dd_clean = dd.filter(lambda x: x[0] not in common_words)
print dd_clean.count()
#
dd_1 = dd_clean.sortBy(lambda x: x[1],ascending=False)
dd_1.toDF(["word","count"]).show(5)

%pyspark
print ("*** RD-DD")
rd_clean.subtractByKey(dd_clean).sortBy(lambda x: x[1],
    ascending= False).toDF(["word","count"]).show(10)

%pyspark
common2 = ['sanders:','clinton:','clinton','sanders','cooper:',"o'malley:","o'malley",'holt:','todd:','ramos:','maddow:',
    'mitchell:','salinas:','webb:','woodruff:','[through','lemon:','ifill:','webb','andrea','chafee:','trump:','trump','rubio:','cruz:',
    'tapper:','bush:','kasich:','blitzer:','kelly:','kasich','carson','baier:','wallace:','carson:','paul:','christie:','fiorina:',
    'bartiromo:','christie','hewitt:','cavuto:','jeb','[applause]','me','your','my','\u2014','said','out','very','huckabee:','—','quintanilla:',
    'harwood:','jake','ben','hugh','baker:','huckabee','walker:','trump?','rand','rubio?','megyn','cruz?','tumulty:','sanders?','chafee',
    'translator]:',"lester","martin"]

%pyspark
rd_clean = rd_clean.filter(lambda x: x[0] not in common2)
print rd_clean.count()
#
rd_1 = rd_clean.sortBy(lambda x: x[1],ascending=False)
rd_1.toDF(["word","count"]).show(5)

%pyspark
dd_clean = dd_clean.filter(lambda x: x[0] not in common2)
print dd_clean.count()
#
dd_1 = dd_clean.sortBy(lambda x: x[1],ascending=False)
dd_1.toDF(["word","count"]).show(5)

%pyspark
print ("*** RD-DD")
rd_1.subtractByKey(dd_1).sortBy(lambda x: x[1],ascending=False).toDF(["word","count"]).show(10)

%pyspark
print ("*** DD-RD")
dd_1.subtractByKey(rd_1).sortBy(lambda x: x[1],ascending=False).toDF(["word","count"]).show(10)

paragraphs.text:
%md
### TF-IDF as Feature Extraction

result.msg: TF-IDF as Feature Extraction

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
documents = sc.textFile("data/sotu/debates/").map(lambda line: line.split(" "))
print documents.count()
print documents.take(3)

result.msg:
26067
[[u'Democratic', u'Candidates', u'Debate', u'in', u'Las', u'Vegas,', u'Nevada'], [u'October', u'13,', u'2015'], [u'']]

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
from pyspark.mllib.feature import HashingTF,IDF
hashingTF = HashingTF()
tf = hashingTF.transform(documents)
print tf.take(10)
#
tf.cache()
idf = IDF().fit(tf)
tfidf = idf.transform(tf)
print tfidf.take(10)

%md
### We can see the features, but not easy to go back to the word vector from the hashes
### TF-IDF is useful as a part of the pipeline towards ML algorithms like Classification
### _That is why HashingTF and IDF are part of pyspark.mllib.feature_

result.msg:
We can see the features, but not easy to go back to the word vector from the hashes

TF-IDF is useful as a part of the pipeline towards ML algorithms like Classification

That is why HashingTF and IDF are part of pyspark.mllib.feature

paragraphs.text:
%md
### ML API to Rescue

result.msg: ML API to Rescue

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
from pyspark.ml.feature import HashingTF, IDF, Tokenizer

sentenceData = sqlContext.createDataFrame([
    (0, "Hi I heard about Spark"),
    (0, "I wish Java could use case classes"),
    (1, "Logistic regression models are neat")
], ["label", "sentence"])
tokenizer = Tokenizer(inputCol="sentence", outputCol="words")
wordsData = tokenizer.transform(sentenceData)
hashingTF = HashingTF(inputCol="words", outputCol="rawFeatures", numFeatures=20)
featurizedData = hashingTF.transform(wordsData)
idf = IDF(inputCol="rawFeatures", outputCol="features")
idfModel = idf.fit(featurizedData)
rescaledData = idfModel.transform(featurizedData)
for features_label in rescaledData.select("features", "label").take(3):
    print(features_label)
